Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 1 of 27
CASE NO. 3:25-CV-0721-BL
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
MIDDLE DISTRICT OF ALABAMA
EASTERN DIVISION
__________________________________________________________________
IN Re: CHRISTOPHER BLAINE McGREGOR,
DEBTOR.
_________________________________________________________________
BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND,
APPELLANT
V.
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE McGREGOR
APPELLEE.
__________________________________________________________________
On Appeal from the United States Bankruptcy Court, Middle District of Alabama,
Eastern Division, Case No. 24-81152-BPC
__________________________________________________________________
BRIEF OF APPELLEE
__________________________________________________________________
Charles M. Ingrum, Jr. (ING-028)
Ingrum & Layson, LLC
830 Avenue A, Ste. B
Opelika, AL 36801
Telephone: (334) 745-3333
FAX: (334) 460-2287
charles@cijllaw.com
December 21, 2025
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 2 of 27
RULE 8012 DISCLOSURE STATEMENT
Pursuant to Fed.R.Bk.P. 8012, the Appellee certifies that:
1.) Debtor/Appellee, Christopher Blaine McGregor, is an individual, the only
Debtor in this matter, and hereby certifies that there are no reportable
relationships that could pose a financial or professional conflict for this
Court.
2.) Other than the sole Debtor, Christopher Blaine McGregor, there is no
creditor’s committee, and no entity whose stock or equity value may be
substantially affected by the outcome of this proceeding. The only other
individual involved is the Creditor/Appellant, Brittany Michelle Gilliland.
Respectfully submitted,, this the 21st day of December, 2025.
/s/ Charles M. Ingrum, Jr.
Charles M. Ingrum, Jr.
Attorney for Appellee
i

CASES PAGE

441 Fed.Appx. 650 (11th Cir. 2011)………………………10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16

294 So.3d 774 (2019)………………………………………………………….….15

Statutes

11 U.S.C. §523(a)(5)………………………………………………………….5, 7, 8
11 U.S.C. §523(a)(15)………………………………………………….…7, 8, 9, 20
11 U.S.C. §1328(a)(2)…………………………………………...……………..8, 20

Code of Alabama §30-2-57…………………………………………………….…15
iv
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 6 of 27
STATEMENT OF THE ISSUES PRESENTED FOR REVIEW
III. The bankruptcy court did not err by classifying
Creditor’s Claim Number 19 as a general unsecured
claim because the debt to the Wife is not a domestic
support obligation.
IV. Changes made by BAPCPA do not support a finding
the divorce court’s equitable distribution of assets a
non-dischargeable, domestic support obligation.
APPLICABLE STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Court reviews the Bankruptcy Court’s conclusions of law de novo,
while it reviews findings of fact for clear error. Jove Eng’g. Inc. v. Internal
Revenue Serv., 92 F.3d 1539, 1545 (11th Cir. 1996). A finding of fact “is clearly
erroneous when, although there is evidence to support it, the reviewing court on the
entire evidence is left with the definite and firm conviction that a mistake has been
committed.” Id. (quoting Elston v. Talladega Cnty. Bd. Of Ed., 997 F.2d 1394,
1405 (11th Cir. 1993)). Edwards V. Colin, 2017 WL 1822570 (M.D.Ala. 2017).
1
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 7 of 27
STATEMENT OF FACTS
1. Christopher Blaine McGregor (hereinafter “Debtor”) and Brittany
Michelle Gilliland (hereinafter “Wife”) were married with two children.
(See Rec. 2).
2. Debtor has no college degree, and worked to put Wife through school,
who received her undergraduate degree as well as her master’s degree in
higher ed. (Rec. 25, Page 28).
3. Wife was earning $60,000.00 to $70,000.00 per year, and was the primary
bread winner in the family. (Rec. 25, Page 28).
4. Debtor believed that Wife quit her job, but later learned that she had been
fired. (Rec. 25, Page 28).
5. Debtor became the primary income for the household. (Rec. 25, Page 28).
6. The Debtor and Wife were divorced on February 27, 2024. (Rec. 2, Page
11).
7. The divorce court awarded the Debtor primary physical custody of the
Parties’ children. (Rec. 2, Page 7).
8. Wife has to pay the Debtor child support. (Rec. 2, Page 9).
9. The divorce court did not award alimony. (Rec. 2, Page 10).
2
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 8 of 27
10. The divorce court awarded the Debtor the marital residence. (Rec. 2,
Page 4).
11. The paragraph establishing the Debtor’s monetary obligation to Wife
states:
“The Husband shall pay to the Wife one-half (1/2) of the
equity in the residence which is fifty-one thousand four
hundred eleven dollars and 21/100 ($51,411.21). This
amount shall be paid as follows: $10,000.00 within 10 days
of this order, followed by monthly payments of $2,000.00 per
month for 21 consecutive months beginning April 1st. The
court is aware that the total of the payments above total
$52,000.00. The additional $588.79 awarded may be
avoided by the Husband by paying the full $51,411.21 within
90 days of this order. Otherwise, the additional $588.79 shall
be consideration for the delay in the Wife receiving full
payment. If the Husband fails to timely make these
payments, then the house shall be placed on the market for
sale with a licensed real estate agent. Upon sale, the net
proceeds shall be equally divided between the parties.” (Rec.
2, Page 5).
12. In the present case, Wife has remarried, and is living with her new
Husband and child from her new Husband. (Rec. 25, Page 20).
13. Wife remarried in less than 60 days after the divorce was final. (Rec. 25,
Page 20).
3
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 9 of 27
14. When the Debtor filed for bankruptcy relief, he listed his obligation to
Wife as a non-priority, general unsecured debt. (Rec. 3, Page 21).
15. The Wife filed her claim as a priority debt based on 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(5),
that it is “for a domestic support obligation”. (Rec. 2, Page 3).
16. The bankruptcy court ruled that Wife’s Debt is not a domestic support
obligation, and shall be paid as a general, unsecured claim. (Rec. 21).
17. Note, the Debtor has always proposed to pay Wife in full at 100% in his
Chapter 13 bankruptcy. (Rec. 6, Rec. 8). Regardless of how this comes
out, Wife is getting all of her money, less anything she has to pay out for
the litigation and appeal. (Rec. 6, Rec. 8).
SUMMARY OF THE ARGUMENT
There are certain debts that a bankruptcy debtor cannot discharge,
they are enumerated in 11 U.S.C. §523(a). Not all of these exceptions
apply in Chapter 13. Child support, alimony, or debts in the nature of
child support or alimony are not dischargeable to a debtor in Chapter 7 or
Chapter 13; however, property division resulting from a settlement
4
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 10 of 27
agreement or divorce decree are excepted from discharge in a Chapter 7,
but free to discharge in a Chapter 13.
The Debtor has primary physical custody of his children; wife pays
him child support. The Debtor nor his ex-Wife were ordered to pay
alimony. The Debtor was awarded the Parties’ primary residence; the
Debtor was ordered to pay Wife ½ of the equity in the primary residence.
The Debtor contends that his obligation to Wife is not in the nature of
support, and therefore dischargeable in Chapter 13. Naturally, Wife
contends that it is in the nature of support. The bankruptcy court agreed
with Debtor and ruled accordingly. Wife has appealed.
ARGUMENT
V. The bankruptcy court did not err by classifying Creditor’s Claim
Number 19 as a general unsecured claim because the debt to the
Creditor is not a domestic support obligation.
When the Debtor filed for bankruptcy relief, he listed the Wife’s claim
as a non-priority, general unsecured debt. (Rec. 3, Page 21). The Wife filed
her claim as a priority debt based on 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(5), that it is “for a
domestic support obligation”. (Rec. 2, Page 3). As a preliminary matter, as
5
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 11 of 27
that the Creditor’s claim is based on 11 U.S.C. §523, “Exceptions to
Discharge”. As such:
“The objecting creditor has the burden of proving
each of these elements by a preponderance of the
evidence. Grogan v. Garner, 498 U.S. 279, 111 S.Ct.
654, 112 L.Ed.2d 755 (1991). If any one of these
elements is not met, the debt is dischargeable. Moreover,
courts generally construe the statutory exceptions to
discharge in bankruptcy “liberally in favor of the
debtor,” and recognize that “’[t]he reasons for denying
a discharge…must be real and substantial, not merely
technical and conjectural.’” In re Tully, 818 F.2d 106,
110 (1st Cir. 1987) (quoting Dilworth v. Boothe, 69 F.2d
621, 624 (5th Cir. 1934); see also Boyle v. Abilene
Lumber, Inc. (Matter of Boyle), 819 F.2d 583, 588 (5th
Cir. 1987). This narrow construction ensures that the
“honest but unfortunate debtor” is afforded a fresh start.
Birmingham Trust Nat’l Bank v. Case, 755 F.2d 1474,
1477 (11th Cir. 1985); see also Caspers v. Van Horne, 823
F.2d 1285, 1287 (8th Cir. 1987) (“[E]vidence presented
must be viewed consistent with congressional intent that
exceptions to discharge be narrowly construed against
the creditor and liberally against the debtor, thus
effectuating the fresh start policy of the Code.”). Miller
v. Equitable Bank, 39 F.3d 301, 304 (11th Cir. 1994)
(emphasis added).
Cited by In re Mitchell, 633 F.3d 1319, 1327 (11th
Cir. 2011) and SuVicMon Dev., Inc. v. Morrison, 991
F.3d 1213, 1225 (11th Cir. 2021).
To apply to the present case, in a light liberally construed in favor of
the Debtor, and strictly construed against the Wife, did the Wife prove by a
6
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 12 of 27
preponderance of the evidence that the Debtor’s obligation to her was a non-
dischargeable debt in the nature of support? The answer is clearly “no”.
In order for the Wife to prevail, she relies on 11 U.S.C. §523(a)(5),
which states that a “domestic support obligation” is non-dischargeable.
A “domestic support obligation” is:
“a debt that accrues before, on, or after the date of
the order for relief in a case under this title, including
interest that accrues on that debt as provided under
applicable nonbankruptcy law notwithstanding any other
provision of this title, that is-
(A) owed to or recoverable by-
(i)A spouse, former spouse, or child of the debtor or such
child’s parent, legal guardian, or responsible relative; or
(ii)A governmental unit;
(B) In the nature of alimony, maintenance, or support
(including assistance provided by a governmental unit) of
such spouse, former spouse, or child of the debtor or such
child’s parent, without regard to whether such debt is
expressly so designated…” 11 U.SC. §101(14A).
This is distinguished from 11 U.S.C. §523(a)(15) which states that a debt is
nondischargeable:
“to a spouse, former spouse, or child of the debtor
and not of the kind described in paragraph (5) that is
incurred by the debtor in the course of a divorce or
separation of in connection with a separation agreement,
7
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 13 of 27
divorce decree or other order of a court of record, or a
determination made in accordance with State or territorial
law by a governmental unit.” 11 U.S.C. §523(a)(15).
In other words, 11 U.S.C. §523(a)(5) states that child support or alimony, or
anything in the nature of child support or alimony is nondischargeable; and
11 U.S.C. §523(a)(15) states that anything else awarded to a former spouse
in a divorce decree or separation agreement (property distribution or
settlement) is nondischargeable. So why the distinction? Why didn’t
Congress just state that anything awarded in a divorce decree or separation
agreement is nondischargeable? Simple, Congress excepted alimony, child
support and anything else in a divorce decree from being dischargeable in a
Chapter 7 bankruptcy; however, Congress only excepted alimony and child
support (not property division) from discharge in Chapter 13. A property
division resulting from a divorce decree or settlement agreement is
dischargeable in Chapter 13. See 11 U.S.C. §1328(a)(2).
Not every exception to discharge listed in 11 U.S.C. §523 applies in
Chapter 13. The only exceptions to discharge under 11 U.S.C. §523 (out of
19 total) that are applicable to Chapter 13 are: “(1)(B), (1)(C), (2), (3), (4),
(5), (8), or (9)” 11 U.S.C. §1328(a)(2). Clearly missing from the list is 11
8
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 14 of 27
U.S.C. §523(a)(15). Therefore, the only type of debt that would be excepted
from discharge, and have to be given priority status in the present Chapter
13 case would be a debt under 11 U.S.C. §523(a)(15) that is a domestic
support obligation, which is a debt that is alimony or child support, or in the
nature of alimony or child support.
In the present case, the Debtor was awarded primary physical custody.
(Rec. 2, Page 7). Wife has to pay him child support. (Rec. 2, Page 9).
Furthermore, the Court did not award alimony. (Rec. 2, Page 10). The
paragraph establishing the Debtor’s monetary obligation to Wife states:
“The Husband shall pay to the Wife one-half (1/2)
of the equity in the residence which is fifty-one thousand
four hundred eleven dollars and 21/100 ($51,411.21).
This amount shall be paid as follows: $10,000.00 within
10 days of this order, followed by monthly payments of
$2,000.00 per month for 21 consecutive months
beginning April 1st. The court is aware that the total of
the payments above total $52,000.00. The additional
$588.79 awarded may be avoided by the Husband by
paying the full $51,411.21 within 90 days of this order.
Otherwise, the additional $588.79 shall be consideration
for the delay in the Wife receiving full payment. If the
Husband fails to timely make these payments, then the
house shall be placed on the market for sale with a
licensed real estate agent. Upon sale, the net proceeds
shall be equally divided between the parties.” (Rec. 2,
Page 5).
9
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 15 of 27
Although this Honorable Court should look beyond express designations as
to the award given, there is nothing in the above paragraph that indicates that Wife
was granted anything other than the equitable distribution of the equity from the
marital residence awarded to the Husband. (See Rec. 2, Page 5). There is nothing
in the language of the paragraph concerning Wife’s financial condition. (See Rec.
2, Page 5).
Secondly, the Wife did not present any evidence in the trial of this matter
that the Debtor’s obligation is in the nature of support other than the convenient
and self-serving statement that she needs the money. Wife did not present any loan
document, tax return, or any document confirming her “belief” in this statement.
This alone should fail the preponderance of the evidence in any court, much less
when it should be construed liberally in favor of the Debtor, and strictly against the
Wife.
Despite the above facts, the Wife uses primarily three cases to support her
contention. They are easily distinguishable from the present case.
In re Benson, 441 Fed.Appx. 650 (11th Cir. 2011). In Benson, the Husband
and Wife agreed that Husband would keep making the mortgage payments on their
10
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 16 of 27
home, in which Wife was still living. Id. at 650. Husband tried to discharge the
mortgage payment as a property settlement. Id. at 651. The Court stated:
“Here the agreement supports Sally’s contention
that the parties intended the mortgage payments to be a
domestic support obligation. Although in the agreement
Sally waived any right to claim alimony, she did so in
consideration for the benefits she received in the
agreement. The agreement also required Todd to
maintain life insurance that would be sufficient to cover
his mortgage obligation. Furthermore, Sally agreed to let
Todd claim a tax exemption for their minor children as
long as he continued paying the mortgage, which made
the payments appear to be child support. And when Todd
failed to pay the mortgage, he was found in contempt in
state court. Last, we note that Todd testified that at the
time the agreement was made Sally had not been working
outside the home for at least a decade.”. Benson at 651-
652.
In the present case, the Wife did not “waive alimony” in consideration for
anything; the Judge made a ruling after hearing the evidence, and awarded
accordingly. The present case was not an agreement of the parties. The Court
awarded the Debtor the marital residence, not the Wife. (Rec. 2, Page 4). The
Debtor has primary physical custody of the minor children (Rec. 2, Page 7), and
unlike the debtor in Benson, could not be held in contempt for not paying Wife the
money the Court awarded her; it is not support. Although there is disparity in the
11
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 17 of 27
Debtor and Wife’s income, “Sally had not been working outside the home for at
least a decade” (Benson at 651-652), perfect facts for an award of alimony. In the
present case, the divorce court reasonably took into consideration that shortly
before the divorce, the Wife made “Between 60,000 and 70,000 (dollars per year).
She was the breadwinner for a long time because I don’t have a college education,
and I was working to help put her through college to earn her master’s degree in
higher ed. And I thought she’d quit her job, but she was (actually) fired. That’s
what we learned during the divorce trial. And she was the breadwinner for a while
for our family” (Rec. 25, Page 28). The Debtor does not have a college degree,
and Wife has a master’s degree. (Rec. 25, Page 28). Wife has the burden, and yet
no evidence was introduced by Wife as to why she does not go back to work or
why she cannot go back to work earning $60,000.00 - $70,000.00 per year. In In re
Benson, there is no statement that Sally has remarried or has cohabitated with
anyone else. In the present case, Wife has remarried, and is living with her new
Husband and child from her new Husband. (Rec. 25, Page 20). If Debtor’s
obligation were in the nature of support, it would be terminated due to her
cohabitation. Code of Alabama §30-2-55. Wife has yet to make this position
known in Alabama divorce court. If Wife’s contention is that Debtor’s obligation
12
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 18 of 27
to her is in the nature of support, then why has she not requested the obligation
stop due to her cohabitation. This leads inevitably to a doom loop that she wants
the bankruptcy court to designate something as support, that under Alabama law
should terminate due to her remarriage and cohabitation. Code of Alabama §30-2-
55. So is Wife’s entire appeal a request for Debtor’s obligation to stop and her get
nothing from her claim because she is no longer entitled to support due to
remarriage and cohabitation?
Furthermore, In re Benson states that there are factors that a court should
consider in a determination as to whether an obligation is in the nature of support:
1.) The agreement’s language: In the present case, this falls squarely in favor of
the Debtor. (Rec. 2, Page 5).
2.) The parties’ financial positions when the agreement was made: First there
was no agreement made, this was a ruling from a trial, and a clear distinction
from the present case. As to the actual financial positions, as stated above,
clearly the divorce court judge and the bankruptcy judge took into
consideration the evidence presented that Wife made $60,000 to $70,000 per
year with a master’s degree, and husband has no undergraduate degree.
13
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 19 of 27
(Rec. 25, Page 28). Although the income is different, the financial position
of a party with a master’s degree is clearly superior to one without any
degree, the income is a result of whether one wishes to utilize it. This factor
is in the Debtor’s favor.
3.) The amount of the division. Here it is clearly detailed that the division of
assets and subsequent payment by the Debtor is based on the equity of the
home, not on some alleged need of the Wife for support. (Rec. 2, Page 5).
Debtor’s favor.
4.) Whether the obligation ends upon death or remarriage of the beneficiary;
Clearly not. (See Rec. 2, Page 5). Debtor’s favor.
5.) The frequency and number of payments. This appears to be aligned with a
repayment designed to match the Debtor’s ability to pay. The Debtor could
have paid it off and saved a little by paying within 90 days of the divorce
decree. Again, there is nothing presented by Wife, or in the language of the
divorce decree that remotely implies that the frequency and number of
payments was designed as support for Wife. (See Rec. 2, Page 5). Wife has
burden, so Debtor’s favor.
6.) Whether the agreement waives other support rights. The divorce decree
14
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 20 of 27
orders no periodic alimony. (Rec. 2, Page 10). However, there was no
“agreement” of the parties. Wife did not “give up” alimony in consideration
for the award of one half of the equity in the marital home. Therefore,
Debtor’s favor.
7.) Whether the obligation can be modified or enforced in state court. Support
can be modified, property distributions or settlements cannot be. (See Code
of Alabama §30-2-57; also See LaFontaine v. LaFontaine, 294 So.3d 774
(2019)). For purposes of this appeal, Wife will probably argue that it is
modifiable because it is ”support”; however, as noted above, this argument
completely fails because if it were actually support, then it would be
modifiable, and her claim should be reduced to $0.00 because she has
remarried and is cohabitating with her new Husband and child. So here,
probably goes to Wife, and should result in reducing the claim to $0.00.
8.) How the obligation is treated for tax purposes. This one is no
longer relevant. Prior to 2018, alimony was considered income for the
recipient, and a deduction for the payor. Payment of alimony is no longer a
taxable event.
15
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 21 of 27
Even based on the factors cited in Benson, the Debtor’s obligation to
Wife to pay her one half of the equity in the marital home cannot be
determined to be in the nature of support. The Wife’s claim is a general
unsecured claim.
Cummings v. Cummings, 244 F.3d 1263 (11th Cir. 2001). In this case
relied on by Wife, the court correctly states that “a court cannot rely solely
on the label used by the parties”. Cummings at 1265. Clearly the
bankruptcy court, nor this Honorable Court can find that the Debtor’s
obligation is in the nature of support solely because Wife says it is; which is
the only evidence she introduced. Furthermore, as to labels, both parties as
well as the divorce court called the Debtor’s obligation to Wife a division in
equity of the marital residence. (Rec. 2, Page 5).
In Cummings, the Court of Appeals determined that a portion of the
Debtor’s $6.3 million equitable distribution was in the nature of support
because “the divorce court indicated several times that Susan Cummings
would depend on a portion of the equitable distribution to support herself
and the children.” Id. at 1266. In quoting the divorce court, the Eleventh
Circuit stated ““[t]he Wife will be able to support herself and the children
16
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 22 of 27
upon receipt of the income-generating assets awarded to her in the equitable
distribution.” Thus, the divorce court declined to award permanent alimony
precisely because it believed that Susan Cummings would be able to support
herself and the children with the proceeds of the equitable distribution.” Id.
This is not the case here. In the present case there is no language by the
divorce court alluding to the fact that any of the equitable division of the
marital property was intended to be in lieu of support. Additionally, the
Eleventh Circuit did not reverse the bankruptcy court; they simply remanded
the matter to the bankruptcy court “to await clarification by the divorce court
regarding what portion – if any – of the equitable distribution is in the nature
of support”. Id. In the present case, how could the divorce court have made
it any plainer? What logically would be the result of the divorce court
revisiting this matter to determine which portion of the equitable division of
the marital residence is in the nature of support? The logical answer would
be “none”.
In Edwards v. Colin, 2017 WL 1822570 (M.D.Ala. 2017), the District
Court reversed the bankruptcy court because “there is no question that the
intent of the parties was for the Settlement to serve as support to Appellant
17
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 23 of 27
in lieu of alimony”. Edwards at 3 (emphasis added). In Edwards, the parties
had been married for thirty two years, and the wife never held a full time job
during the marriage, and was not working at the time of the divorce. See Id.
at 1. Prior to the final divorce, the parties in Edwards went to mediation,
and the district court considered testimony from the mediation that “”the
alimony be reclassified as property settlement and reduced to $750.00 per
month.” Which appealed to Appellant because it could not be modified and
because it would not be taxable to her, and appealed to Appellee because it
was a lesser amount per month”. Id. Additionally, “in reviewing the record,
it s obvious that the Settlement was intended as support for Appellant”. Id.
at 2.
In the present case, there was no settlement agreement from mediation
that the divorce judge entered. There was no evidence that the Wife “gave
up” anything. The Debtor’s obligation arises from a full trial ore tenus, in
which the judge reached a determination. There is nothing clear or even
ambiguous that any portion of the order from the divorce court determined
that the equitable division of the parties’ marital residence had anything to
do with support.
18
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 24 of 27
Additionally, the court in Edwards stated that “the Settlement was not
in actuality a settlement of the marital property as “there is really nothing
being divvied””. Id. at 3. In the present case it is clear that the equity in the
house was being “divvied”, and each got one half. (Rec. 2, Page 5).
Wife keeps claiming the disparagement in income as an argument,
which the court in Edwards took into consideration; however, there was
nothing in Edwards that demonstrated that Sara Edwards had a master’s
degree, and was the primary bread winner for years until she was fired, and
that Allen Colin did not even have an undergraduate degree, as are the facts
in the present case. The court in Edwards stated that “it is abundantly clear
that the parties mutually intended the Settlement to achieve the same goal as
alimony”. Id. at 3 (emphasis added). There is nothing “abundantly clear” in
the present case that the parties mutually intended the property division to
achieve the same goal as alimony. As that the Wife’s attorney wanted to
make it abundantly clear in bankruptcy court that Wife remarried in less than
60 days after the divorce was final, she probably had no desire for any of her
award to be classified as alimony; as that, but for this bankruptcy, would
have been terminated in less than 60 days after it was awarded. (Rec. 25,
Page 21-22).
19
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 10 Filed 12/21/25 Page 25 of 27
VI. Changes made by BAPCPA do not support a finding the divorce
court’s equitable distribution of assets a non-dischargeable,
domestic support obligation.
The Wife’s argument here is nonsensical. Basically, the Wife argues
that because the changes to the bankruptcy code in 2005 (BAPCPA)
removed the “balancing test” from 11 U.S.C. §523(a)(15) that a distribution
of marital property is non-dischargeable. As noted above, 11 U.S.C.
§523(a)(15) does not apply in Chapter 13 cases. See 11 U.S.C. §1328(a)(2).
The rest of Wife’s argument is just recycled argument of Issue I, with the
self-serving claim that she believes the division of equity of the marital
home is in the nature of support, without anything else to substantiate it.
CONCLUSION
The Debtor’s obligation to Wife is not in the nature of support,
therefore not a domestic support obligation, and therefore dischargeable in
Chapter 13.
Respectfully submitted, this the 21st day of December, 2025.
